page.title: 03St Bridget's Church,
page.content: St Bridget's Church, Bridgerule Evidence of William Vinnicombe's work can also be found in Bridgerule Parish Church where he made the church floor consisting of 18,000 old roof slates, laid tiles in the chancel and installed the old heating apparatus and flues. Still remaining in the church from ancient times is the Saxon Font. St. Bridget's Church was built in the 12th Century but the first tomb was laid in 1600. There are about 4,000 people buried in the churchyard. During the war one of the "ears" of the tower was knocked off but there have never been any break-ins. Standing well above the village, its tower is crowned with turrets and pinnacles. It is a much loved church.
